questions.text: Which electrophysiological activity is responsible for the T wave in ECG?
questions.solution:
The T wave in ECG is due to ventricular repolarisation.

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text:
The PR intervals obtained from the ECG recording of 4 patients are given below. Which of the following patients has a normal PR interval?

Patient 1- 0.19s

Patient 2- 0.3s

Patient 3- 0.23s

Patient 4- 0.1s
questions.solution:
The normal duration of the PR interval is 0.12-0.2 seconds (3 to 5 small boxes).

PR interval is said to be prolonged if it is > 0.2 seconds and short if it is < 0.12 seconds.

It is measured from the beginning of the P wave to the beginning of the QRS complex. It represents the time from the start of atrial depolarization to the start of ventricular depolarization.

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

(QT minus QRS)

questions.text: What is the normal QRS interval?
questions.solution:
The normal duration of the QRS interval is normally 0.1-0.11 seconds (less than 3 small boxes).

QRS interval represents the duration of ventricular depolarization. When the QRS complex is > 0.11 seconds, it is called a wide QRS complex. It can occur in:

  • Bundle branch blocks (RBBB or LBBB)
  • Depolarizations originating in the ventricles
  • Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome
  • Hyperkalaemia

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

questions.text: Which lead does the given ECG tracing represent in a normal ECG?
questions.solution:
As all the waves (P, QRS, T) are negative in the given ECG, it should be lead aVR. All the depolarisations waves (P, QRS, T) move away from lead aVR in the normal sinus.

Depolarisation wave moving towards the positive pole of the lead (or active electrode) produces a positive deflection in the ECG and depolarization moving away from the positive pole of the lead produces a negative deflection in the ECG.

The lead aVR provides information from the right upper side of the heart.

 

The given image shows a normal 12 lead ECG:

questions.text: In a normal ECG obtained from a patient, a biphasic P wave may be seen in which of the following lead(s)?
questions.solution:
In a normal ECG, a biphasic P wave is seen in lead V1 only.

Lead V1 is a chest lead. So, it records potentials in the horizontal plane. The P wave in lead V1 consists of:

  • Positive component reflecting right atrial depolarization (due to anteriorly oriented vector)
  • Negative component reflecting left atrial depolarization (due to posteriorly oriented vector)

questions.text: Which of the following leads would show maximum R wave with the cardiac axis as +90 degrees?
questions.solution:
With the cardiac axis at +90 degrees, lead aVF would show the maximum R wave. 

The cardiac axis represents the mean QRS axis (direction of mean depolarization vector).

The normal adult QRS axis is directed downward and to the left, which is between -30 degrees and +100 degrees.

The position of lead aVF is at +90 degrees. If the cardiac axis is also at +90 degrees, it would be in the same direction as lead aVF and hence aVF would show maximum R wave amplitude.

If the mean axis is:

  • More negative than –30 degrees: left axis deviation
  • More positive than +90 to +100 degrees: right axis deviation
  • Lies between -90 to +180 degrees: extreme axis deviation

Related Pearl: ECG Leads

LA – Left arm: RA – Right arm: LL – Left leg: LF – Left foot

  • Limb leads measure the electrical activity in the frontal plane
  • Chest leads measure the electrical activity in the horizontal plane


Limb Lead Location Augmented limb leads Location Chest leads Location
+ -
I LA

  RA aVF LF +ve V1 4th intercostal space. just to the right of the sternum
II LL

  RA aVL LA +ve V2 4th intercostal space. just to the left of the sternum
III LL

 LA  aVR RA +ve V3 midway between V2 and V4
  V4 Midclavicular line. fifth intercostal
V5 Anterior axillary line, same level as V4
V6 Midaxillary line, the same level as V4 and V5

questions.text: Pseudo P pulmonale is seen in which electrolyte abnormality?
questions.solution:
Pseudo P pulmonale refers to tall peaked P waves seen in hypokalemia.
P-pulmonale refers to P waves taller than >2.5mm in an ECG lead.

Hypocalcemia (Option C) prolongs the QT interval.

Hypercalcemia (Option D) shortens the QT interval.

questions.text: Which of the following ECG findings are seen in a patient with hypokalemia?

choices.text: Prolonged PR interval with ST elevation
Decreased PR interval with ST depression
Decreased QT interval with tall T waves
Prolonged QT interval with flat T waves

questions.solution:
Prolonged QT interval with flat T waves is seen in hypokalemia.

Hypokalemia prolongs ventricular repolarization. The ECG changes seen are as follows:

  • Flattening of T wave
  • ST-segment depression
  • Prolongation of QT interval
  • The appearance of U wave

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with a long-standing history of rheumatic heart disease comes to the clinic with complaints of dyspnea. Interpret the ECG finding.
questions.solution:
The P waves in the given ECG are broad and notched. This is the P mitrale pattern which is seen in left atrial enlargement.

This patient has likely developed mitral stenosis (heard as a mid-diastolic murmur) secondary to his rheumatic heart disease. Mitral valve stenosis and atrial inflammation in rheumatic carditis lead to left atrial dilation. 

The features of P mitrale are:

  • lead II: broad (>2.5mm) notched P waves
  • Lead V1: Biphasic wave with a prominent negative terminal component (representing delayed depolarization of the LA)

P pulmonale is seen in right atrial enlargement. 

Option A: The rabbit ear pattern is seen in the right bundle branch block. The ECG of RBBB below shows the rSR' pattern of the QRS complex (rabbit ear) in leads V1-V2 and slurred S wave in lead V6.

Option D: Sawtooth pattern in ECG is seen in atrial flutter (shown below).

questions.text: A 67-year-old man with a history of COPD presented with worsening dyspnea for 2 weeks. On examination, pedal edema was present. An ECG was done and lead II showed the following pattern. Which of the following is responsible for this ECG finding?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, a peaked P wave can be seen. This is called P pulmonale and it is seen in cases of right atrial enlargement. The patient is showing features of heart failure possibly as a consequence of dysfunction caused by the overload. 

Signs of heart failure in this patient:

  • Bilateral pitting edema in lower extremities (systemic congestion)
  • Worsening dyspnea due to increased PCWP causing pulmonary hypertension and pulmonary edema (pulmonary congestion)

The features of P pulmonale include:

  • The amplitude of the P wave is >2.5mm on Lead II
  • Prominent positive wave in the biphasic P wave of lead V1

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of this patient based on the given ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows deep S-waves in V6 and large R-waves in V1. This is suggestive of right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH).

Diagnostic criteria for RVH:

  • Dominant R wave in V1 (R/S ratio > 1).
  • Dominant S wave in V5 or V6 (R/S ratio < 1).
  • Right ventricular strain pattern - ST depression/T wave inversion in the right precordial (V1-4) and inferior leads (II, III, aVF)
  • Right axis deviation of +110° or more.

For left ventricular hypertrophy, Sokolow Lyon criteria are commonly used.

It is based on the presence of tall left precordial R waves and deep right precordial S waves (S wave in V1 + [R wave in V5 or V6] >35 mm).

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency room with complaints of sudden onset chest pain that radiates to the left arm and jaw. He is profusely sweating. An ECG was taken immediately. Interpret his ECG.
questions.solution:
The patient has a myocardial infarction (MI) with ECG changes of a left bundle-branch block (LBBB), which can be identified by the following classical features:

  • Wide QRS complex- QRS ≥120 ms 
  • Predominantly negative (QS) complexes in lead V1 and entirely positive (R) complexes in lead V6.
  • M pattern seen in left chest leads (V5, V6) 

MI can have the following ECG changes:

  • ST-segment elevation- zone of injury
  • T wave depression
  • Deep Q waves- late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of LBBB: Mnemonic WILLIAM (W pattern in V1-V2; L-LBBB; M pattern in V3-V6)

The ECG findings below are characteristic of RBBB: Mnemonic MARROW (M pattern in V1-V2; R-RBBB; W pattern in V3-V6)

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient comes to the emergency room with a history of severe retrosternal pain radiating to the jaw. The patient initially felt some uneasiness while eating lunch after which he experienced pain. His ECG is as shown. Interpret his ECG.
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows ST-segment elevation in the anterior chest leads suggestive of myocardial infarction.

Features of MI on ECG:

  • ST-segment elevation: Zone of injury
  • T wave inversions
  • Deep Q waves: late sign to develop
  • New left bundle branch block (LBBB)

Option A: Atrial flutter shows a sawtooth wave pattern. 

Option B: WPW syndrome shows delta waves.

Option D: Ventricular tachycardia has wide QRS complex and increased heart rate.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency room complaining his heart is pounding and that he is going to die. The emergency physician orders an ECG. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows ST elevation in leads V1-V4 which is suggestive of acute anteroseptal myocardial infarction (MI). ST depression in the leads III and aVF signifies an old inferior wall infarction.

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic man presents with retrosternal chest pain and profuse sweating and lightheadedness. Based on the ECG findings, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows ST elevations in leads I, aVL, and V1-V6. This is suggestive of extensive anterior wall MI.

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the given ECG?
questions.solution:
The ECG is suggestive of lateral wall MI and possible posterior wall MI.

ST-elevation is present in the high lateral leads (I and aVL) and in V5 and V6.

Reciprocal ST depression is seen in the inferior leads (III and aVF) with associated ST depression in V1, V2, and V3 (which could represent posterior wall MI).

This pattern is consistent with an acute infarction localized to the superior portion of the lateral wall of the left ventricle (high lateral STEMI).

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with chest pain on the left side radiating to the arm and jaw on the same side. Cardiac troponins are found to be raised. What is the diagnosis based on this ECG?
questions.solution:
The given ECG is of posterior wall MI.

The ECG findings in posterior wall MI include,

  • Reciprocal ST depressions in leads V1 to V3. Posterior wall ischemia is indirectly recognized in this way
  • Tall and broad R waves (>30ms) in V2 and V3
  • Dominant R waves (R/S ratio > 1) in V2
  • Upright terminal portions of the T waves in V2 and V3
     

Related Pearl: Localisation of MI based on ST elevations in different leads

Extensive anterior - I, aVL, V1-V6

Lateral - I, aVL

Inferior - II, III, aVF

Anteroseptal - V1-V4

Anterolateral - I, aVL, V3-V6

Posterior - ST depression and tall R in V1-V4

questions.text: Which of the following ECG findings are unlikely to be present in a patient with hyperkalemia?
questions.solution: Prolonged QT interval is not a feature of hyperkalemia, it is a feature of hypokalemia.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the ER with complaints of multiple episodes of vomiting, increased frequency of urination, and constipation for the past 5 days. He also complained of lethargy and muscle pain. He is a known case of SCC of the lung. What is likely to be seen in the ECG of this patient?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of hypercalcemia due to ectopic production of PTH-related peptides. It is mostly associated with squamous-cell lung cancer (SCC). ECG is likely to show a decreased QT interval.

Hypocalcemia shows increased QT interval.

questions.text: ECG of a patient revealed a QT interval of 0.55s. Which of the following will not be a differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
QT interval of 0.55s suggests QT prolongation. It is not seen in digitalis toxicity. Rather, a QT shortening with characteristic “scooping” of the ST–T-wave complex, called a digitalis effect, is seen.

The ECG changes seen in digitalis toxicity are as follows:

  • Prolonged PR interval
  • ST-segment depression
  • Short QT interval

QT interval represents the time taken for the ventricles to depolarize and repolarize. It is prolonged in the following:

  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Congenital long QT syndromes such as Romano-Ward syndrome
  • Hypothermia
  • Drugs: Class IA and Class III antiarrhythmics
  • Intracranial bleeds: particularly SAH

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

questions.text: Osborn waves in ECG are seen in:
questions.solution:
Osborn waves are seen in hypothermia.

Osborn waves can also be seen in severe hypothyroidism (Option A), but even in those cases, hypothermia is the reason for the appearance of Osborn waves. Therefore, hypothermia is the better answer here.

It consists of an abrupt ascent right at the J point (the junctional point between the QRS complex and the ST segment) and then an equally sudden plunge back to the baseline. It is also called the J wave. This is because systemic hypothermia prolongs repolarisation.

Osborn wave can also be seen in:

  • Hypercalcemia
  • Brain injury
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage
  • Vasospastic angina
  • Cardiopulmonary arrest from oversedation
  • Idiopathic ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: In a patient with a left-sided massive pneumothorax, all of the following ECG changes are seen except:
questions.solution:
Right axis deviation is seen in left-sided pneumothorax. 

The ECG changes seen in left-sided pneumothorax are as follows:

  • Reduced R wave amplitude
  • Inversion of T wave in precordial leads
  • Amplitude changes in QRS complex
  • Right axis deviation
